Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2010 10:16AM ordinarymammal wrote: Thank you so much for sharing your experiences!  It feels similar to my teenage experiments with pot--which I found unpleasant.  The panicked feeling of will I ever come down?  After 5 days of this, the high feeling has subsided somewhat (praise be to all that is kind and merciful!) but is still nagging.  The standard chemo brain symptoms have worsened this round--my latest blip was replying to someone's email request for information with some chit chat, but forgetting, in the time it took to type the darn thing, to include the information.   Multitasking ability is almost non-existent.  Short term memory is wiped out. I am now on the cusp of a treatment decision.  As I like to proudly proclaim to anyone who will listen, 'My brain is my favorite part of my body."   My job, as a floor nurse, (which I LOVE) requires me to keep track of and think excellently about five patients at once.  The name of the game is interruptions--with numerous phone calls, changes in orders, family members stopping me in the hall, or me leaping after an MD that I've spotted disappearing around the corner.  If I can't regain my previous level of functionng, my career is toast.  Last night I was looking at material (blogs, articles, etc) by Idelle Davidson, who wrote a book called Your Brain After Chemo.  The studies showing chemo causes permanent brain damage are growing, and the people who write of their difficulties are heart breaking.   Chemo brain is a stupid, cutesy term for a condition that is devastating.  Once again, as I have been so many times on this cancer journey, I am appalled.
Posts.Title: Unreal, high feeling--is this chemo brain? ordinarymammal ordinarymammal

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 06:33PM ordinarymammal wrote: I'm so glad to see this thread.  I go for bilateral mastectomy this Friday without reconstruction.  I have always been DD or greater, and I am intrigued to see what flat life will be like.  I am overweight, but committed to getting back into shape.  Used to run in college, after binding up with two or three different sports bras, and still hating the bounce.  I did promise my teenage boys that I wouldn't go out in public flat--guess I'll have to find some training bras and stuff in some kleenex--am amazed at how expensive the prostheses are. But maybe I can sneak off to run flat around the track in the dead of night! Maybe, one day, I'll be so tired of no chest that I'll beg for "reconstruction."  But at least, I'll be doing it because I know that's what I want. The flat choice was a surprise for me.  It's purely to please myself.  I would have gotten immediate reconstruction to please my husband, but he didn't seem to care either way. Wish me luck on Friday. (23rd)
Posts.Title: I'd rather be flat than fake...I think. Suzybelle robinlbe

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2010 07:32PM ordinarymammal wrote: Day five post op.  BS removed the dressings and I have steristripped lumpy incisions that the BS says should flatten out nicely.  He says he did a little cosmetic surgery to remove the extra fat (under my armpits, I think?) so I could be nice and smooth like I had asked.  Call me a weirdo, but I think it looks kinda cute.  I've always been HUUUGE (can you say "H" nursing bra?) and this is a fun difference. The drains are hemovac drains, like two CD's held an inch apart by springs.  I pinned them up on the outside of my compression bra where breasts might have been, and put on bulky sweatshirts, and went out to lunch.  I got nervous when I was browsing in the bookstore, because I looked down and could see the outline of the drains under the shirt and thought I might get stopped for attempting to shoplift CD's. I'm overweight and can't believe I never realized just how big my stomach is.  When I get the drains out, I'm going to start running, and I'm going to jump on trampolines, and I may never wear a bra again!
Posts.Title: I'd rather be flat than fake...I think. Suzybelle robinlbe

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2010 10:22PM - edited Jul 13, 2010 10:29PM by ordinarymammal Hi Bluesky and lamuso I am in the middle of chemo (TC x 4) and have been absolutely freaking out over how foggy and impaired I've been, and wondering if it is "permanent." I just bought this book, "Your Brain After Chemo" (2009 Silverman and Davidson). Dan Silverman MD, PhD is UCLA researcher and Idelle Davidson is a journalist who went through breast cancer therapy.  I have only skimmed the book so far, but (1) They say neuroimaging shows cognitive changes 5-10 years post chemo (2) tamoxifen can increase the cognitive impairment...and (3) there are diet, physical, pharmaceutical, and lifestyle changes you can make to improve cognitive function.  Here is an article they wrote called "What to ask your doctor about post-chemo brain": http://news.cancerconnect.com/your-brain-after-chemo/ Here is a blog where folks are telling their stories: http://yourbrainafterchemo.blogspot.com/ There is a NY Times article by Jane Brody describing what they suggest for recovery, but I can't remember how to find it... I still don't have enough information about whether I will recover from the damage I might have already inflicted on myself, and whether there is any way to protect my brain if I decide to continue with the recommended 4 rounds. Edited to include wikipedia article on "Post-chemotherapy cognitive impairment" en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-che...
Posts.Title: Foggy Brain-3 Years After Chemo Treatment bluesky Joviangeldeb

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2010 05:20PM ordinarymammal wrote: Whew, the high feeling has finally passed.  I can now declare myself symptom free! jsm1946 Sorry you're going through the decision-making lows before chemo. I'm not surprised you're finding most of your info on the discussion boards. I'm a nurse who works on the oncology unit of my hospital, and I find most of my info...on the discussion boards. A quick note about penguin cold caps to try to prevent hair loss. Unless your oncologist is extraordinary, he/she will pooh pooh them, either saying they don't work or else because of worry of scalp metastases (yes, breast cancer can spread to the scalp). Cold caps are highly experimental in the US--only about 200 women have tried them--though there has been great success in Europe (which apparently doesn't count as far as US oncologists are concerned).  There are published (non-US, I'm afraid) reports showing no increased scalp metastases.  I'm day 32 cold capping on TC. Still have my hair. Could be cold caps, could be luck. They ARE a mega hassle, though, and expensive too.   But I'm going to continue with them, just in case they work. About icing nails, I'm surprised your onc hasn't said anything, it's so well known. Look at "docetaxel" on wikipedia for heaven's sake: half way down the page there's a photo of a smiling woman getting Taxotere (docetaxel) and icing her nails. My recurrence score was 25 and chemo probably only gives me a 3% benefit. I think I would have been happier doing chemo if I got your whopping 7% benefit. Then again, precious little makes me happy about cancer, these days!  Also, I decided to do chemo because I see so many women have difficulties with tamoxifen and AI's.  According to the 6/28/10 Journal of Oncology, only 49% of women who embark on tam or AI's finish a full 4.5 years.  If I end up one of the "non-adherent" women, I expect to be grateful to myself for addressing the cancer scourge with chemo.
Posts.Title: TC Chemo really not bad so far KGBinDC KGBinDC

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 05:56PM ordinarymammal wrote: Bon  I had blinding headache for 4-5 after my first infusion.  So bad, kept checking myself for symptoms of stroke.  Did not have stiff neck. I figured it was from Cytoxan, which I guess can cause headache. Oncologist said Aloxi and Zofran are from a class of drugs that can cause headache (5-HT3 receptor antagonists).  I still did Aloxi second round and took only 2mg zofran day #3 (when I figured the Aloxi might have worn off).  Decadron dose was reduced this round, too.  No headache! Second round, no real side effects at all (unlike first round), except for disturbing spacy high feeling that started day #3 and stupid chemo brain dysfunction.  I am so worried that I might be suffering permanent brain damage, that I am seriously considering stopping chemo and asking to move on to the 5 years of tamox or AI. But don't mean to be a downer here on this upbeat thread.  Apart from being so worried about my brain--and doing idiotic things like brushing my teeth with Lamisil, losing my purse, and sending out nonsense emails--this round has been a piece of cake.!
Posts.Title: TC Chemo really not bad so far KGBinDC KGBinDC

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 08:38PM ordinarymammal wrote: Rayofsun: I see you were to have surgery April 15, and also that you've recently updated your original post.  I hope your surgery went well and that your recovery is going smoothly.  Thank you again for maintaining this thread.  I have found the tips and reports and encouragement from the other women here invaluable.  I have occasional freakouts, and reading about everyone here calms me right down.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 03:42PM ordinarymammal wrote: Had bilateral mastectomy with left SLN biopsy--I think the surgeon only took 1 node. It's funny how different surgeons have different procedures.  As soon as I was walking the morning postop, the surgeon was telling me I should be windmilling my arms. I went home postop day #2-- with no activity, lifting or driving restrictions; "make sure to do your exercises;" and two 400 ml Hemovac style drains, each draining two tubes per side.  Different from the bulb jackson-pratt drains I'd seen other mastectomy patients using. The tubing is incredibly thick and sturdy; there's no way I could squeeze it to "strip" the tubing, but then again I think the drains have quite a bit of suction power--some large rasty gooey clot thingies have been sucked into and trapped in them.  They have three springs inside and I need to use both hands to flatten them against a hard surface after emptying them. In the hospital, I used a LOT of IV morphine through the patient controlled pump and came home on percocet.  I still need to take a couple during the day and two before bed.  I take 300 mg of docusate and 2 senna a day, but even with a high fiber diet, I'm not as regular as I'd like.  Not much appetite, either, though I know I should be forcing the good nutrition for healing. I have great range of motion, though when I stretch the left side, there's a little difficulty and pain before it loosens up. All in all, things have been much easier than I anticipated.  I've walked a couple of miles every day, but still haven't had the courage go out in public. My heart is full for all the women who have posted on this thread.  I wish ease, and health, and hope to all of you.  Your courage and grace and honesty have buoyed me up.  I hate being a member of the breast cancer club, but I'm pretty proud to be a member of the April Mastectomy Thread.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: May 7, 2010 09:02PM ordinarymammal wrote: ssashland: So sorry to hear your news.  I am another one who tumbled off the DCIS train into scary IDC territory. My heart goes out to you.  irishtess:  My birthday was supposed to be in may, but I'm congenitally impatient and was born 4/26.  I'll be thinking of you may 11.  May the lilt of Irish laughter lighten every load...May the mist of Irish magic shorten every road...And may all your friends remember every favour you are owed. My left site seroma and infection are improving, with the antibiotics and the penrose drain.  I tell you though, that penrose drain (soft rubber tube flapping out a hole under my armpit, I've seen them on dogs) is a real psychological challenge.  The drainage is down to a small dribble now (direct onto bandages) and the redness is much better, but still!  Eeeyuw!  I combed this site and found very little mention of penrose drains..  Hopefully, my surgeon is some sort of genius, and not a veterinarian posing as a BS.  Of course, I AM an ordinary mammal...
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2012 04:29PM ordinarymammal wrote: Yes, I used Penguin Cold caps in 2010 during taxotere and cytoxan and kept my head hair.  A friend undergoing taxotere and cytoxan at the same time lost her hair.  When she underwent a round of adriamycin and cytoxan in 2011, she asked me to apply elastogel cold caps to her head and she kept her head hair.  I found out about cold caps on the thread Cold Cap Users Past and Present to Save Hair, started in June of 2009. http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/6/topic/735873?page=1 Best wishes to you in your breast cancer journey.
Posts.Title: Hair loss prevention Mimi8 Ang7

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2010 07:46PM ordinarymammal wrote: I hope you have already found the Penguin Cold Caps thread elsewhere on this site. If not, Penguin Cold Caps are rented out by MSC, Medical Specialties of California, which is actually based in the UK. This is the address of their website. http://www.msc-worldwide.com/index.html On the website is information about how to contact them.  Since your upcoming chemo is soon, you might prefer to call. I had 2 rounds of taxotere with cytoxan followed by 2 rounds of single agent taxotere, and I used the cold caps.  I did keep my hair. Best of luck with your treatment.
Posts.Title: penguin cold caps redninrah ordinarymammal

Posts.Content: May 5, 2010 07:37PM ordinarymammal wrote: Had my bilateral drains out on monday, felt nothing when they were removed, started an occasional low grade fever pretty soon after, then antiobiotics, then had to have a 35cc seroma drained today.  The surgeon put in a penrose drain, yuck!, I remember seeing them on dog abscesses when I was little.  It just drains out onto sterile dressings, which I will be changing pretty often, barking all the while. I hear everyone about the belly  There is no way my belly was this big before.  I even took some laxatives to make sure it wasn't the backup due to percocet.  Salads and gym visits have never looked so good.  As my BS so quaintly put it, I had a "high vavoom factor"; my husband may be in shock, but I can't help but secretly think my flat chest looks cute and sporty.  I, too, am on the emotional roller coaster.  I had had "extensive" DCIS and then the pathology came back with two microinvasions plus IDC 0.9cm.   Great margins, clear lymph nodes, hormone receptors lining up nicely, but... not the birthday present I was asking for. I think the fever whacked my mood around, too. And I'm being so darned upbeat yet realistic (knowing that the reality is of course very very hopeful) for my kids, besides the normal teenage parenting issues, that it isn't until I'm alone and awake at 02:30 that I mourn, and I mourn heavily, the fact that my DCIS journey couldn't just be over and done with via bilateral mastectomy. My PCP gave me some samples of lexapro, but I'm just too chicken to mess around with my seratonin. It's been so great reading everyone's updates and questions on this thread.  April 2010 sure was a month to remember, wasn't it? Please please please keep us updated for a long time to come.
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: May 24, 2010 12:48PM ordinarymammal wrote: My oncotype score came back in the intermediate range, the estimate is 16% risk of recurrence in 10 years.  It's not clear how much benefit chemo gives me, but I'm willing to try to shave off a few percentage points.  Will start 4 3-week cycles of taxotere and cytoxan, probably the day after my 18-year-old son graduates. Urk!  Maybe I should start chemo earlier: it really would be the perfect excuse to get out of the sweltering, outdoor graduation ceremony, with those "inspiring" speakers and the faulty sound system. Ok.  The "mommy police" just knocked on my door and issued a citation. Back to the original plan: first glad grad and then sick chick. Anyone else ever tempted to try to pull "the cancer card" for special consideration?  It's not worked real well for me yet...
Posts.Title: april 2010 masectomy rayofsun jessamine

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 02:50PM ordinarymammal wrote: NativeMainer  I wish you were treated better.  How horrible it must be to have all that crap on top of fighting the breast cancer itself. It sounds like care was so abysmal across the board, that I'm wondering if it wasn't only you that was treated so poorly.  I have heard of places where the "culture of care" spirals downward, and anyone who tries to buck the trend gets slapped down, or gets burned out and leaves. (At the very least, I think more than 2 IV tries per nurse is inhumane, and they should have a policy against it. ) Sounds like I've been very lucky to have been a med/surg/onc nurse and also a med/surg/onc patient that was treated very well. iodine i loved reading the list of different jobs you've done. It makes me hopeful that if I can't go back as an onc nurse, that there are a variety of interesting things I could do. rgiuff my onc laughs at me too.  Last time I went in, he grabbed my list of 20 or so questions, and said "I shouldn't let you sit in the waiting room so long thinking up more questions."  Calls me a pain in the, but at the same time, he really likes being challenged.  We play dueling studies.  I, too, get more useful information here on the discussion boards and the other areas of bc.org than almost anywhere else.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10

Posts.Content: May 25, 2010 09:17PM ordinarymammal wrote: I'm a med/surg/onc nurse.  After surgery, I spent 2 nights on my own unit, and it was WONDERFUL.   My BF is a float nurse at the same small hospital, and she spent those two nights in a cot in the room with me.  I have to say I wasn't treated like a nurse by the staff, but like a cherished friend.  They did laugh at me some when I insisted on d/cing the foley myself--wasn't too interested in having a coworker perform that service for me.  And for my part, I did my best to talk incessantly when they were trying to auscultate my lungs.  We also had a good laugh, because staffing accidentally scheduled me to work the day I went in to surgery, and it took a bit of scrambling to cover for me. You're so right about not seeing the post-hospital follow up care.  I knew vaguely about seromas, but it took several of my nurse friends who were coming over to my house for my dressing changes to make me acknowledge that I had developed one. Treated like a nurse: Sometimes I don't get the explanations I need, but often it seems I get too much standard explanation.  It's hard not to break in and say, "Come on, I know this stuff already."  I work hard to "play patient" because I'm afraid if I interrupt the spiel, I might miss out on some information that I really needed.  I sure do know how to ask questions, though, having worked so hard helping patients ask their own questions.  I do worry my colleagues will think I am stupid, but unfortunately, the "impressing others with my smarts" ship sailed a long time ago, and although I am a bit of a moron, maybe I get points for smart questions. I was in the process of getting "chemo certified" when I was diagnosed, and I tried hard to continue at work (thinking I "only" had DCIS, with no chemo in my future) and continue training, but I was stress stupid.  As surgery neared, I didn't think I was a safe, smart nurse, and I stayed out.  Now when I think of receiving the infusions that I was learning to give--and suffering the SE's I was educating and medicating others for--I am shocked and appalled.  I don't think there is any way I could drum up the mental sharpness and physical stamina and emotional reserves to work while I'm undergoing chemo. Plus hospitals are so full of germs. I'm a fairly new nurse--graduated in 2006, as a 44-yr-old.  Worked nights for 3 years, only on days for a few months before dx.  One of my fellow grads, a wonderful friend, worked nights only a few months at the beginning, but was dx'd with IDC a year ago.  My BF has worked nights--loves it--for at least 10 years and is fine.
Posts.Title: Nurses with Breast Cancer Jo_Ann_K PatRN10
